analytic.title: Transcriptome analysis provides insights into hepatic responses to moderate heat stress in the rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss)

abstract.p: The rainbow trout is an economically important fish in the world. The limited stress tolerance of this species to high summer-like temperatures usually leads to mass mortality and great economic loss. However, there is limited information on the mechanisms underlying moderate heat responses in the liver of the rainbow trout. Here, we performed transcriptome profiling of rainbow trout liver under moderate heat stress by using the Hiseq™ 4000 sequencing platform. More than 277 million clean reads were obtained from 6 libraries and aligned against the rainbow trout genome. A total of 128 unique transcripts were differentially expressed in the liver under heatstress and control conditions, many heat shock protein genes for thermoregulation and some novel genes involved in heat stress were identified. Nine of the differently expressed genes were further validated by qRT-PCR. Gene ontology and Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes analyses revealed that several pathways, including those for protein metabolism, energy metabolism, and immune system, were influenced by heat stress. Moreover, an important protein-processing pathway in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER) was identified, and the key role of ER-associated degradation and function of calpain as an upstream regulator of apoptosis were confirmed under heat stress. The results of this study provide a comprehensive overview of heat stress-induced transcriptional patterns in rainbow trout liver and would be particularly useful for further studies on the molecular mechanisms underlying responses to heat stress in this species.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Fish are ectotherms and usually exposed to daily or seasonal temperature fluctuations in their aquatic environments. Although fish can cope with some ranges of temperature variations through physiological plasticity or micro-evolution, severe diseases and death occur when they exceed their thermal tolerance capability (Whitehead et al., 2011;Bellard et al., 2012). Therefore, physiological responses and thermal plasticity have become the focus of current stress research, given the growing threat of global warming. The rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss) is a cold-water salmonid species that is native to the Pacific coast of North America. In 1959, it was introduced to China and cultivated as the main variety because of its delicious taste and high nutritional value. The rainbow trout usually grows in the temperature range of 8 to 22°C, whereas the water temperature above 25°C is perilous for their survival (Matthews and Berg, 1997); the appropriate growth temperature is 12-18°C, and food intake and growth are impaired at temperatures above 20°C. The limited stress tolerance of the rainbow trout to high summer-like temperatures, especially in the cage culture environment, usually leads to mass mortality and great economic loss. Investigating the molecular mechanisms underlying heat stress in the rainbow trout will contribute to understanding its adaptation mechanism to thermal conditions and promote the development of heat-resistant breeding and technology for this species.

Over the past several decades, researchers have studied the physiological and molecular responses to heat stress in fishes; in particular, approximately 80% of the known heat-shock protein (HSP) genes in fish have been cloned and characterized, and almost twothird of the identified HSP genes belong to the HSP70 family (Deane and Woo, 2011). However, heat stress responses are complex and not limited to a single or few regulatory genes or proteins. Recently, high-throughput analysis has been used in genetic and conservation genetic studies of various non-model animals, including studies of genome-wide changes in gene expression in ecologically important fish, and it provides detailed molecular information on the regulation of genes involved in physiological processes under conditions of temperature shock (Ekblom and Galindo, 2011).

Microarrays are the predominant means of studying gene expression changes, and they have been used to study the responses of coral reef fish (Kassahn et al., 2007), Atlantic killifish (Healy et al., 2010), sockeye salmon (Jeffries et al., 2012;Jeffries et al., 2014), brown trout (Meier et al., 2014), and Pacific bluefin tuna to temperature (Jayasundara et al., 2013); a lot of valuable information has been obtained from these studies. However, microarray technologies have some drawbacks when compared with RNA sequencing (RNA-seq) technology, such as high background signal and prior knowledge of the gene sequences (Shendure, 2008). In the barramundi (Newton et al., 2013), gilthead sea bream (Mininni et al., 2014), Atlantic crimson spotted rainbowfish (Smith et al., 2013), olive flounder (Hu et al., 2014), large yellow croaker (Qian and Xue, 2015), redband trout (Narum and Campbell, 2015), snow trout (Barat et al., 2016), Iberian chub and Mira chub (Jesus et al., 2016), data on gene and expression levels after temperature treatments were obtained using RNA-seq because it allows for the analysis of whole transcriptomes with high accuracy and reproducibility of detection and a greater dynamic range (Marioni et al., 2011).

The rainbow trout is a major commercial fish, and some studies on the heat stress responses of the rainbow trout have been conducted. The transcript levels of HSC70a, HSC70b, HSP47, HSP27, HSP90a, HSP90b, and HSP60 were changed when the rainbow trout underwent heat stress by HSP cloning and characterization Ojima et al., 1681;Ojima, 2007;Shi et al., 2015). In 2010, Lewis published a paper on transcriptome responses to heat stress in the nucleated red blood cells (RBCs) of the rainbow trout by using microarrays and investigated the differences in RBC global gene transcription under control conditions (11°C) and heat stress conditions (1 h at 25°C, followed by recovery at 11°C) (Lewis et al., 2010). To the best of our knowledge, it was the first study to provide an overall description of the transcriptome of teleost RBC and track stress responses at the mRNA level. Then, comparative analysis of transcriptome profiling between different rainbow trout strains was performed to reveal candidate genes responsible for upper temperature tolerance and different strategies used for coping with thermal stress (Tan et al., 2012;Rebl et al., 2013;Verleih et al., 2015;Tan et al., 2015). Tan et al. performed RNA-seq analysis of 5 tissues in 2 strains of rainbow trout to investigate the genes related to upper temperature tolerance by administering 30 min of acute heat stress and found that the HSP genes and genes related to transcription factor AP-1 are constantly expressed 2-fold or more in almost all the tissues (Tan et al., 2015). Rebl et al. identified differences in temperature-induced gene expression in the gill and kidney of native and imported strains and suggested links between the different temperature-dependent pathways and gene networks after a 2-week acclimation to mild heat by using the microarray approach (Rebl et al., 2013;Verleih et al., 2015).

In the present study, because the temperature in the actual aquatic environment rarely increases sharply, we administered moderate heat stress by increasing the temperature at a relatively constant speed (increments of 1°C per 24 h) from 18°C to 24°C. The liver is the crucial metabolic organ associated with stress response, and little is known about the mechanisms underlying heat response in rainbow trout liver. Therefore, we focused on the transcriptome analysis of control rainbow trout liver (OM_CL) and heat-treated rainbow trout liver (OM_HL) to identify related genes and pathways regulated by heat stress; 128 differentially expressed genes (DEGs) and several important pathways were identified. The results of this study will not only be helpful in understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying heat stress in the rainbow trout but also provide valuable genetic information for heat-resistant breeding of this species under climate change conditions. To our knowledge, this is the first publicly available global transcriptome study of rainbow trout liver under moderate heat stress conditions.

div.head: Experiment design and sampling
div.p: Rainbow trout (400 ± 10.5 g in weight) specimens were obtained from a trout farm in Yongjing, Gansu Province, China, and they belonged to full-sibling inbreeding families. The fish were transported to our laboratory and cultured in a 3000-L aerated water tank at a temperature of 18°C. After 7 days of acclimation, the fish were randomly divided into 6 groups and acclimated for another 7 days in 300-L water tanks prior to the experiment. Then, the fish were treated with heat stress by using a temperature system that could continuously increase the temperature at a constant speed (increments of 1°C per 24 h). The temperature change was considered to approximately simulate the natural temperature increase in cage culture waters. The fish were anesthetized with a lethal dose of MS-222 before tissue sampling. The livers of female specimens at 18°C (control group) and 24°C (heat-treated group) were collected immediately, flash-frozen in liquid nitrogen, and stored at −80°C until RNA extraction. All the animal experiments were performed according to the Chinese Legislation on the Use and Care of Laboratory Animals and the protocol approved by the institutional ethic committee of Gansu Agricultural University (GSAU).

div.head: RNA isolation, library preparation, and sequencing
div.p: Total RNA was extracted from the liver samples by using the standard TRIzol protocol (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA), and the RNA was checked using the NanoPhotometer® spectrophotometer (IMPLEN, CA, USA) and agarose gel electrophoresis. RNA concentration and integrity were assessed using the Qubit 2.0 fluorometer (Life Technologies, CA, USA) and Bioanalyzer 2100 System (Agilent Technologies, CA, USA).

A total of 3 μg of RNA per sample was used as the input material for RNA sample preparations. Six sequencing libraries were generated using the NEBNext® Ultra™ RNA Library Prep Kit for Illumina® (NEB, USA), according to the manufacturer's instructions, and index codes were added to attribute sequences to each sample. Briefly, mRNA was purified from the total RNA by using poly-T oligo-attached magnetic beads and broken into short fragments by using divalent cations under elevated temperature in NEBNext First Strand Synthesis Reaction Buffer (5×). First-strand cDNA was synthesized using M-MuLV Reverse Transcriptase (RNase H − ) and random hexamer primers, and the reaction buffer, RNase H, and DNA polymerase I were added to synthesize second-strand cDNA. The remaining overhangs were converted into blunt ends via exonuclease/polymerase activities. After adenylation of the 3′ ends of the DNA fragments, NEBNext Adaptor with hairpin loop structure was ligated before hybridization. The library fragments were purified using the AMPure XP System (Beckman Coulter, Beverly, USA) to select 150-200-bp cDNA fragments. Then, the fragments with ligated sequencing adapters were enriched using PCR amplification. The PCR products were purified with the AMPure XP System, and library quality was assessed using the Agilent Bioanalyzer 2100 System.

Clustering of the index-coded samples was performed using the cBot Cluster Generation System with the TruSeq PE Cluster Kit v3-cBot-HS (Illumina, CA, USA), according to the manufacturer's instructions. After cluster generation, the library preparations were sequenced using the Illumina Hiseq™ 4000 platform, which generated 150-bp paired-end raw reads.

div.head: Data analysis of mRNAs
div.p: The raw reads were processed using in-house Perl scripts. Only clean data (clean reads) were used for the subsequent analysis, and they were obtained by removing the reads containing the adapter or poly-N (N 10% unidentified nucleotides) and low-quality reads. Q20 (percentage of bases with a Phred value N 20), Q30 (percentage of bases with a Phred value N 30), and GC (bases G and C) contents of the clean data were calculated. The rainbow trout reference genome and gene model annotation files were downloaded from the genome website (https://www. genoscope.cns.fr/trout/) (Berthelot et al., 2014). Index of the reference genome was created using Bowtie v2.2.3, and the sequences were aligned to the reference genome by using TopHat v2.0.1.2 (Trapnell et al., 2012). The read numbers mapped to each gene were counted using HTSeq V0.6.1. The expression level of each gene was estimated using expected number of fragments per kilobase of transcript per millions base pairs sequenced (FPKM), which is currently the most frequently used method for estimating gene expression levels (Trapnell et al., 2010).

DESeq R package 1.18.0 was used for the differential expression analysis between 2 groups (3 biological replicates per condition), and adjusted p-value b 0.05 identified using DESeq was set as the threshold for differential expression (Anders and Huber, 2010). Gene Ontology (GO) enrichment analysis of DEGs was performed using the GO seq R package (Young et al., 2010). The Kyoto Encyclopedia of Genes and Genomes (KEGG) pathway (http://www.genome.jp/kegg) annotations were generated using the KEGG database, and statistical enrichment of DEGs in the KEGG pathways was analyzed using KOBAS software (Mao et al., 2005).

div.head: Quantitative real-time (qRT)-PCR analysis
div.p: According to potential functional importance, 9 DEGs were selected for further validation by using qRT-PCR with the total RNA used for RNA-seq. The PrimerScript™ RT Reagent Kit with gDNA Eraser (TaKaRa, Dalian, China) was used to synthesize first-strand cDNA. Gene-specific primers were designed using Primer Premier 5.0 according to each identified gene sequence of the liver transcriptome library (Table S1). The expression of each sample was checked in triplicate by using SYBR® Premix Ex Taq (TaKaRa, Dalian, China) and LightCycler® 480 Instrument II (Roche, Switzerland) in 20-μL reaction volumes, according to the manufacturer's instructions; β-actin expression showed no response to temperature in the preliminary experiments, so β-actin was used as the internal reference (Shi et al., 2015). The cycling parameters were as follows: 95°C for 30 s, followed by 40 cycles at 95°C for 5 s and 60°C for 30 s; disassociation curve analysis was performed to check amplification specificity. Each relative expression result was calculated using the ΔΔCt method and subjected to statistical analysis with the SPSS software (version 21).

div.head: Overview of mRNA libraries
div.p: To identify differentially expressed mRNAs in the liver of rainbow trout in response to heat stress, 6 cDNA libraries-the control group (OM_CL1, OM_CL2, and OM_CL3) and heat-treated group (OM_HL1, OM_HL2, and OM_HL3)-were constructed and sequenced using the Illumina Hiseq™ 4000 sequencing platform. The sequencing totally generated 287,277,772 raw reads, which were deposited to the National Center for Biotechnology Information (NCBI) with the accession number of SRP092649. After removing the low-quality raw reads, 39.4-47.8 M clean reads were obtained from each library. The total read length was 41.65 Gb for the 6 samples. The major characteristics of the 6 libraries, including error rate and GC content, are summarized in Table 1. The clean reads were aligned to the whole genome of rainbow trout by using TopHat v2.0.12. The results showed that the ratios of the clean reads mapped to the rainbow trout genome were 66.17-68.61% (Table 1). Because of the rainbow trout genome assembly was incomplete, the mapped ratios were a little bit lower than 70%, but it is well-known that the analysis results based on genome are more reliable than de novo transcriptome analysis. The read numbers mapped to each gene were calculated and normalized to FPKM to assess the gene expression levels; FPKM interval and total genes in each library are shown in Table S2. In the samples, 43.39-51.07% of the mRNA transcripts were detected as FPKM N 1. Pearson's correlation coefficients (R 2 ) of 2 individuals in the same group were checked on the basis of the FPKM value of each sample to reflect the accuracy and reliability of the results; the closer R is to 1, the higher the similarity of the expression pattern between samples. Generally, R N 0.8 was considered suitable. The value of R was 0.92-0.93 among OM_CL1, OM_CL2, and OM_CL3 and 0.882-0.916 among OM_HL1, OM_HL2, and OM_HL3, which confirmed the sufficiently high similarity between the 3 biological replicates of the 2 rainbow trout groups ( Figure S1).

div.head: DEGs between OM_CL and OM_HL groups
div.p: After mapping to the rainbow trout genome, 27,796 genes were obtained from the OM_CL and OM_HL libraries; 1452 genes were only expressed in OM_CL, 2332 genes were only expressed in OM_HL, and 24,012 genes were co-expressed in both groups (Fig. 1A). On the basis of DESeq analysis with adjusted p b 0.05 as the threshold, a total of 128 DEGs between the OM_CL and OM_HL groups were screened ( Fig. 1B). Of these, 46 genes were downregulated with a range of fold change from − 2.72 to − 20.79, and 82 were upregulated with a range of fold change from 2.83 to 50.69. Among these DEGs, 4 genes (CHEK2, GSONMT00074015001, Novel01381, and Novel03362) were only expressed in OM_CL, and 8 most highly differentially expressed genes (| log2 Fold-change | N 4) included HSP90AA, Novel02550, HSP90AB, HSP47A, PHC2, Novel003334, GLT8D2, and CAPN1; 68 genes were mildly induced under heat stress (2 b | log2 Fold-change | b 4). Details of the DEGs, including their full names, p-value, and adjusted p-value, are shown in Table S3. Then, hierarchical clustering based on the gene expression patterns was performed, and the results showed that the 6 samples could be sorted into 2 distinct groups after the heat treatments (Fig. 2). The global gene expression profile of rainbow trout in the OM_HL group showed large differences when compared with the OM_CL group under heat shock conditions.

div.head: GO enrichment and KEGG pathway analysis
div.p: To evaluate the biological and functional implications of the DEGs in response to heat stress, GO and pathway enrichment analysis were performed using the GO and KEGG databases. We focused on biological process and molecular function for GO enrichment analysis; 13 significant GO categories were enriched (p b 0.01), including protein folding (GO:0006457), protein metabolic process (GO:0019538), unfolded protein binding (GO:0051082), heparin binding (GO:0008201), metabolic process (GO:0008152), hydrolase activity (GO:0016813), acute-phase response (GO:0006953), DNA replication initiation (GO:0006270), glutamine metabolic process (GO:0006541), ATPase activator activity (GO:0001671), DNA-dependent DNA replication (GO:0006261), hydroxymethylglutaryl-CoA synthase activity (GO:0004421), and acute inflammatory response (GO:0002526) (Fig. 3). Except for protein metabolic process and metabolic process (25 and 53 DEGs, respectively), most GO terms were represented by a few DEGs (Table S4). We also performed KEGG pathway enrichment analysis. A total of 16 pathways were enriched with a cut-off criterion of p b 0.1 after heat stress (Fig. 4). Among these pathways, "protein processing in the endoplasmic reticulum (ER)" was the most enriched pathway, and 10 genes were enriched in this pathway. Other pathways included "folate biosynthesis", "nucleotide-binding and oligomerization domain (NOD)-like receptor signaling pathway", "arginine and proline metabolism", "progesterone-mediated oocyte maturation", "terpenoid backbone biosynthesis", and "biosynthesis of amino acids" (Table S5).

div.head: Validation of DEGs by using qRT-PCR
div.p: The expression profiles of 9 DEGs were further validated using qRT-PCR during the temperature treatment. Both the direction and magnitude of gene expression changes were largely consistent with RNAseq, although quantity variances were found between the 2 analytical platforms (Fig. 5). The expression fold changes of DEGs measured using these 2 methods were highly correlated with a significant coefficient of determination of 0.97. These results also confirmed the reproducibility and reliability of RNA-seq.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: Because of global warming, the weather is becoming hotter for longer periods, and many cold-water fish are dying during these periods of extreme weather, especially those in the net cage culture models. The rainbow trout is a popular cold-water fish that experiences temperature stress during the hot summer months. The liver is a major organ used to study the pathways of thermal adaptation because of its function of metabolism adjustments to stress adaptations. In this study, liver transcriptome profiles of the rainbow trout in response to heat stress were obtained and analyzed using next-generation sequencing technologies. Numerous DEGs, key biological processes, and several important pathways involved in heat stress were found in the OM_CL and OM_HL groups. The results indicated that the genes related to heat stress may play important roles in facilitating fish survival, and many biological processes were altered under high temperature conditions.

div.head: Gene expression in response to heat stress in the liver
div.p: All organisms must respond to environmental stress to maintain homeostasis. Protection of cellular macromolecules through molecular chaperoning is a cardinal hallmark of cell stress response, and its importance has been well established by comparing transcriptomic and proteomic data from diverse taxa (Logan and Buckley, 2015). A prominent group of molecular chaperones for macromolecules is the HSP family, which is highly conserved and present in all organisms. HSPs can maintain cellular protein homeostasis under stress conditions by refolding thermally damaged proteins and preventing their cytotoxic aggregation (Feder and Hofmann, 1999). In Tomanek's review, HSP expression and regulation among various fish species and variable thermal environments were discussed (Tomanek, 2010); however, these previous studies and data obtained in many cases can only be viewed as causal evidence. Studies on the transcriptional regulation of HSPs and response mechanism to heat stress in a variety of contexts are still required.

In rainbow trout liver, HSP90AA, HSP90AB, HSP47A, and HSP40 were among the top 10 regulated genes at 24°C when compared to 18°C. The HSP90 family proteins are highly abundant and ubiquitous molecular chaperones that are critical for a cell's response to stress and maintenance of cellular homeostasis (Csermely et al., 1998;Jackson, 2013). The expression levels of HSP90AA and HSP90AB increased 50.7-and 29.7fold, respectively, in rainbow trout liver, and they belong to the HSP90α cytosolic isoforms associated with cell cycle regulation and stress-induced cytoprotection (Sreedhar and Csermely, 2004). HSP47A, a substrate-specific molecular chaperone, is a stress-inducible protein localized in the ER (Hirayoshi et al., 1991;Nagata, 1996). The protein is essential for the post-translational folding of fibril-forming collagens and can ensure the stability of procollagen under stressful conditions (Nakai et al., 1992). HSP40 binds to HSP70 through a Fig. 2. Hierarchical clustering of differentially expressed (DE) mRNAs among the 6 libraries. conserved J domain and facilitates cellular recovery by regulating the ATPase activity of HSP70 proteins (Kelley, 1998;Qiu et al., 2006).

Other temperature-regulated HSP-encoding genes included HSP47B (10.8-fold), HSC71 (3.9-fold), HSPA8 (3.9-fold), HSPD1 (3.8-fold), HSP90BA (3.3-fold), HSPE1 (3.1-fold), and HSP90BB (3.1-fold). In the gene database, at least 2 different HSP47 transcript fragments were available for the rainbow trout. Rebl et al. demonstrated that HSP47A in the gill and kidney was strongly upregulated, but HSP47B was depressed after mild heat stress (Rebl et al., 2013;Verleih et al., 2015). In our study, the 2 HSP47 transcripts were both upregulated after heat stress. HSP90B is also present as duplicate variants A and B in rainbow trout . Modern salmonids are pseudo-tetraploids, and about 50% of the gene duplicates may be retained (Bailey et al., 1978;Hurley et al., 2007). Accordingly, besides HSP47 and HSP90B, CDC37 (HSP90-co-chaperone) showed 2 gene duplications, and the expression levels were upregulated 4.6-fold and 4.2-fold, respectively. The information of HSPD1 and HSPE1 was limited in the rainbow trout with 3.8-fold and 3.1-fold induction, respectively. Although AHSA1 is a non-HSP, as an activator of the 90-kDa HSP ATPase homolog, it is also induced 4-fold under heat stress.

In general, the regulation of HSPs or genes relevant to HSPs indicated that they can protect the rainbow trout from heat stress by mediating diverse cellular functions, such as cell death and survival, as well as elevating their transcript levels (Ryckaert et al., 2010). Although the intensity can vary considerably depending on the magnitude and duration of heat stress, species, and tissue, the importance of transcriptional regulation of HSPs was confirmed.

div.head: Metabolism response to heat stress in the liver
div.p: Metabolism in ectothermic fish is highly dependent on environmental temperature during stressful conditions (Somero, 2010). The liver is an important organ for metabolic activities in fish, and it plays a crucial functional role in cellular metabolism and biosynthetic and detoxification activities (Houlihan et al., 1986). In many types of fish, such as zebrafish (Vergauwen et al., 2010), olive flounder (Hu et al., 2014), and large yellow croaker (Qian and Xue, 2015), altered metabolic rate is one of the most rapid cellular responses to increased temperature. In the present study, the functional classification and annotation of differential genes were performed using GO and KEGG analyses. These gene categories are mainly associated with changed metabolism. Under biological process, higher numbers of GO terms were assigned to protein metabolic process, metabolic process, glutamine metabolic process, primary metabolic process, cellular protein metabolic process, and isoprenoid metabolic process. Pathway analysis also showed that metabolic pathways such as metabolism of cofactors and vitamins, amino acids, terpenoids, polyketides, xenobiotics, and lipids represented the most abundant pathways. This indicated that the regulation of metabolic processes is an important part of temperature response in the rainbow trout. The transcript levels of most genes associated with metabolism, such as GCH1, ARG1, HMGCS1, ALAS1, CYPLA3, and several novel genes, were downregulated in a temperature-dependent manner. Among these genes, CYPLA3 belongs to the cytochrome P450 (CYP) system and has widespread functions such as oxidization of a variety of structurally unrelated compounds, including steroids, fatty acids, and xenobiotics (Mininni et al., 2014;Nelson et al., 1996). Nonchemical exogenous parameters, such as environmental temperature and season, regulate the response of the CYP system (Sarasquete and Segner, 2000). Significant downregulation of CYPLA3 suggested that the uptake of xenobiotics and the metabolic rate were reduced and that the demand for metabolic enzymes was also appropriately decreased.

div.head: Immune response
div.p: Previous studies were able to confirm that temperature has a severe impact on the immune system of teleosts, including rainbow trout (Rebl et al., 2013;Verleih et al., 2015;Bowden et al., 2007). In this study, when the rainbow trout encountered mild temperature stress, heat-regulated genes involved in the immune response-NOD-like receptor (NLR) signaling pathway belonged to the HSP90 family. The intracellular NLR family is composed of N20 members that have been demonstrated to function as regulators of the innate immune response against microbial pathogens. However, only NLR proteins are correctly folded and maintained in a recognition-competent state at the appropriate cellular location to function as sensors. Misfolded or used sensors are a threat to the cell and may cause inappropriate activation of downstream pathways that must be immediately inactivated and discarded. Such maintenance of NLR-type sensors requires a structurally and functionally conserved chaperone complex that consists of HSP90 and its cochaperone suppressor of SGT1 (Shirasu, 2009). In addition to NOD1 and NOD2, 2 prototypic NLRs, a different set of NLRs, including NALR1, NALR3, and Ipaf, induces caspase-1 activation through the assembly of an Fig. 5. Log2FC refers to the log2 Fold-change. Fig. 4. Scatterplot of enriched KEGG pathways for differentially expressed genes (DEGs) between OM_CL and OM_HL groups. Rich factor is the ratio of the DEG number to the total gene number in a certain pathway. The size and color of the dots represent the gene number and range of the q value, respectively. inflammasome (Shaw et al., 2008). When the water temperature is increased, the fish immune systems are challenged by modified pathogen spectrums or low dissolved oxygen, but increased expression of stress proteins will contribute to the activation of the innate and adaptive immune systems (Pockley, 2003;Bowden, 2008). In rainbow trout, significant upregulation of HSP90 family expression levels may be indirectly influenced by the immune system through the activation of NALP3 by SGT1 to induce caspase-1 activation under heat stress.

div.head: Protein processing in the ER pathway
div.p: The ER is a subcellular organelle in which proteins are folded with the help of lumenal chaperones. In protein processing in the ER pathway, proteins that are terminally misfolded bind to BiP and are directed towards degradation through the proteasome in a process called as ERassociated degradation (ERAD). When encountering heat stress, the expression levels of HSP70 and HSP90, which participate in the ERAD process in rainbow trout, were upregulated to promote the degradation of damaged proteins. Besides HSPs, protein disulfide isomerase associated 3 (PDIA3), which is a member of the PDI family and mainly located in the ER, has been demonstrated to bind to specific DNA sequences that encode DNA repair proteins involved in the stress response (Chichiarelli et al., 2007). CCT3 is the gamma subunit of the T-complex protein-1 (TCP1) complex, which belongs to the HSP60 family protein, and it plays a pivotal role in the folding of actins, tubulins, and other proteins in an ATP-dependent manner and assembly of cytoskeleton protein(s) as an individual or complexed with other subunits (Archibald et al., 2000;Bhaskar et al., 2012;Amit et al., 2010). Structural proteins would be at a disadvantage under high temperature conditions, and their misfolding and/or denaturation contributes greatly to protein aggregation (Lee and Lai, 1995). Previous studies have indicated increased expression of cytoskeletal proteins in response to temperature stress in teleosts (Rebl et al., 2013;Verleih et al., 2015;Podrabsky and Somero, 2004;Buckley et al., 2006). In the present study, experimental temperature changes from 18°C to 24°C triggered the regulation of structurally associated genes (PDIA3 and CCT3) that assist in the folding of a large number of proteins of multiple structural classes and complex topologies and ensured the recovery and maintenance of normal liver functions in the rainbow trout.

Among the genes enriched by the protein processing in the ER pathway, CAPN1, which is a ubiquitous calpain isoform, was the only gene downregulated in response to heat stress, and it exhibited an 18.66fold decrease in expression level. Calpain is involved in several physiological processes, such as cell-cycle regulation, activation of transcription factors, differentiation, and apoptosis (Saido et al., 1994;Squier and Cohen, 1996). Apoptosis is a genetically programmed process for the elimination of damaged or redundant cells by the activation of caspases (aspartate-specific cysteine proteases). Caspase-12-mediated apoptosis is a specific apoptotic pathway of the ER. Calpain is an upstream regulator of apoptosis, and it can promote or prevent apoptosis indirectly through activation or inhibition of caspase-12 activation.

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this study, the transcriptome analysis demonstrated that heat stress caused numerous changes in gene expression, and it provides a comprehensive overview of transcriptional patterns in rainbow trout liver. A large number of DEGs were identified between the control group and heat-stress group, and some well-described genes for thermoregulation, such as HSP47, HSP90, and HSP70, were also activated. In addition, many novel genes like CYPLA3, CCT3, and PDIA3 are possibly involved in thermal acclimation processes. Multiple pathways involved in the metabolism of amino acids, cofactors and vitamins, lipids, terpenoids, polyketides, and xenobiotics and immune systems were influenced by heat stress. Moreover, a key protein processing pathway in the ER was identified, and the essential role of ERAD and function of calpain as an upstream regulator of apoptosis were confirmed. Our results contribute to understanding the molecular mechanisms underlying responses to challenging temperatures in the rainbow trout and provide a theoretical basis for heat-resistant breeding of this species under climate change conditions.
